bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Gustaf E. Lambert, December 27, 1946

div1.p: Hench rebuts Lambert's claim that Ames was a member of the Yellow Fever Board, replacing Lazear. He explains the criteria to be eligible to receive a pension and/or medal for participation in the yellow fever project.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Gustaf E. Lambert, December 27, 1946
div1.opener:
Copies sent to Kean
Truby
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
December 27, 1946
Mr. Gust Lambert
8009 Avalon Avenue
Chicago 19, Illincis.
My dear Mr. Lambert:
div1.p:
I do apologize to you most sincerely for keeping your data so long.
The delay was not entirely due to procrastination. I wanted to show some of
your items to others--notably to General Kean and General Truby-- so that they
could perhaps give you and me some help and information on certain debated
points and I was postponing my reply to you until I could send you (with your
data) what comments they might have.

You were here on June 20 and 21, 1946. That following week I went to
San Francisco where I had a nice visit with General Truby. I showed him the
papers you had leaned me, also a copy of our interview of June 21. He wanted me
to leave it with him so that he could read it over at his leisure. I did and
later I received the interview back with certain comments written thereon by
General Truby.

Last month I had occasion to go to Washington, D. C. and spent a day
with General Kean. As I promised you I would do I showed him also that copy of
Special Order No. 83 (Quemados, November 14, 1900) and told him your opinion
that that order in effect made Doctor Ames a member of the Yellow Fever Board
replacing Lazear. Meanwhile I have had your items photostated here as you
graciously permitted me to do and I am therefore returning herewith to you the
following:
1) letter from Winifred Lewis - February 16, 1943
2) letter from Mattie Rogers
3) article about Miss Warner - “A Modern Nightingale”
4) photostat letters from Moran and from Wilson
5) copy of letter from R. K. Thomason to Doctor Brumby
6) article and resolution by Doctor Brumby

I have retained the photostat copy of S.O. 83 as I believe you said you had
extra copies and were kind enough to say I could keep this one. If I am in error,
I will have this one copied and return it to you at once.

Now let me transmit to you some of the comments of Generals Truby and
Kean. I am sure they have considered your opinions with real understanding and
sympathy but I will tell you to what extent their opinions differ from yours.

First with regard to Special Order No. 83. You will note that this
order, dated at Quemados, November 14, 1900, is a Headquarters order of the
Department of Western Cuba. It is not an order which originated in Washington
from the War Department, or from the Surgeon General, or through the A.G.O. The
order (paragraph 2) specifically states: “Upon the recommendation of the Chief
Surgeon” (that was Major Kean, I believe) "Dr. Ames was to report for temporary
Mr. Gust Tawbert
-2-
December 27, 1946
duty to Major Reed.

In the opinion of Generals Truby and Kean (given to me separately and
independently of each other) this order did not make Doctor Ames a member of the
Yellow Fever Board any more than did paragraph 1 of the same order make Forbes,
Morris, and Kissinger members of the Yellow Fever Board. Just as paragraph 1
temporarily assigned Forbes, Morris, and Kissinger to help Major Reed temporarily
(at Camp Lazear) so paragraph 2 temporarily assigned Doctor Ames to help Reed. To
have made Doctor Ames actually a member of “A Board of Officers” (the Yellow Fever
Board) created by A.G.O. Special Order No. 122 par. 32-34, Washington, May 24, 1900,
would have required an order originating in Washington (from the S.G.O. or A.G.O. or War
Dept.) amending the original order creating the Board. No such order affecting
Ames exists so far as anyone knows.

Kean and others in charge of local personnel in Quemados and at Camp
Columbia could order certain of their personnel to serve temporarily with Reed.
They had that authority. But nobody in Cuba had the authority to amend a War
Department order creating a Special Board. Had Reed asked for an official replace-
ment for Lazear he would have communicated to the Surgeon General a request for
such an official replacement probably suggesting to the Surgeon General the name
of the person he (Reed) would prefer. Actually Lazear was never officially replaced.
We are all sure of that. I have spent days in Washington going over thousands of
old items, orders, etc. I found no order replacing Lazear or concerning Ames and
the Board.

I am entirely aware of the wonderful contribution Doctor Ames made to the
work of the Board but I beleeve anyone who would try to get official proof that Ames
became a member of the Board would be doomed to disappointment. Doctor Brumby may
decide not to publish his paper with his opinion on this point until he checks the
matter with Washington. This could be done quite simply, I believe. Records re-
garding military personnel are kept in the A.G.O. and in the National Archives. I
believe the A.G.O. would probably now only have an outline of Doctor Ames' record
but the original papers, orders, etc. concerning Doctor Ames would have been trans-
ferred to the National Archives, A.G.O. or S.G.O. Historical Division. Had Dr. Ames
actually been made an official member of the Yellow Fever Board there would be
evidence in the form of orders and records more impressive than that afforded by
S. O. 83.

In the attempts of yourself and Doctor Brumby to obtain further honors
and recognition for Doctor Ames would it not be more profitable to drop attempts
to prove that he was a member of the Yellow Fever Board or to get him placed on
the Yellow Fever Roll of Honor, etc. (which efforts have failed or will be doomed
to failure, I am sure, as Mr. R. E. Thomason advised Doctor Brumby)? Would it not
be better to honor Doctor Ames in other ways, for example, as I hope to do by
articles based on the record and facts of his excellent help to Major Reed. I
certainly plan to honor Doctor Ames in my book by showing his full provable part
in the work. Doctor Brumby might want to start a movement to erect a memorial
plaque to Doctor Ames in his medical school (or some more impressive honor).
Doctor Brumby may wish to publish an article about Doctor Ames in his State Medi-
cal Journal or some national journal. Perhaps the town where Doctor Ames was
born would name a street in his honor, or a medical annex or dispensary. There
are many ways to honor him--ways that would enlist generous support and not in--
volve unhappy controversies. But any article about Doctor Ames should, of course,
be carefully checked and rechecked so as to conform to the publishedofficial records.
The story of Doctor Ames based on such sure grounds is stimulating enough to make
his family and friends proud of it without “spoiling” it with controversial matter.
I personally believe that the family and friends of Doctor Ames will be pleased, and
Mr. Gust Tawbert
-3-
December 27, 1946
I hope satisfied, by my book (whenever it gets published) and its part devoted
to Doctor Ames. Incidentally, I intend to indicate also your own fine contri-
bution in like manner.

Now let me discuss other points raised by our interview of June 21, '46.
Please do not feel hurt by the following remarks. As you know the memories of
all of us play curious tricks and we don't have to be very old to experience the
results of a fallacious memory. I have been checking into the record and dates and
I do think you are mistaken in your interpretation of the role you ascribe to
General Kean. You seem to believe that he had it in for you and perhaps also for
Doctor Ames. I am absolutely sure this is not so. I have spent many hours, indeed
many days, during the past six years questioning General Kean on all phases of the
Yellow Fever story. He has repeatedly told me of many, many details--of his illness,
of Doctor Ames, of you, etc. At no time did he ever as much as infer anything but
full and due respect for what Doctor Ames did, for what you did, etc.

You seem to believe that Major Kean had something to do with Doctor Ames'
transfer to Pirotechnia and with your “blank description blank.” Two or three
years ago General Kean was kind enough to lend me his diaries. I poured over them,
checking dates, facts, etc. Among other things his diaries gave, of course, his own
movements, transfers, etc. These records would indicate that when Doctor Ames was
transferred and when you were also transferred (August, 1901) Major Kean had nothing
whatever to do with it. He himself had already been transferred to other work.
After November 15, 1900, he was no longer Chief Surgeon. For awhile he was on
General Wood's Staff(after May, 1901) in charge of the Havana's city hospitals and
charities. I am therefore absolutely sure of two things: 1) Major Kean had nothing
to do directly or indirectly with these transfers; 2) there was no punitive motive
of any sort in these(routine)changes.

Later in our interview you expressed the belief that when Ames asked
permission of the Surgeon General's Office to borrow Cuban material “Major General
Kean, who was acting Surgeon General,” refused unless Ames would put his request
through channels. You stated that Ames “was at that time a Major and Commanding
Officer and refused to do this so he never got permission.” Let me comment on this.
Kean was never a Major General and was never Acting Surgeon General Ames. was never
a commissioned officer so obviously he was never a Major and presumably never a
Commanding Officer. If Doctor Ames didn't get the material he wanted simply because
he refused (through hurt feelings or pride?) to repeat his request through regular
channels (as practically every military person must do to this day) should one blame
someone in Washington who suggested this? I think there is a misunderstanding about
this whole episode.

I know you will be glad to have some of these misunderstandings done away
with. I do so much hope that in your own feelings you can be much happier, freed of
the feeling that you or Doctor Ames were discriminated against. From all I can hear
and read both of you did your duty most admirably and only kind and generous words
can be, or have been, said of you both. You should continue to have a deep satis-
faction for what you did so well. I personally am very glad indeed to have had the
privilege of meeting you, of talking to you, of hearing your story, of getting your
valuable help. I will never forget it. It is probable that I will need more help
from you and I do hope I can stop off in Chicago again soon. Your visit to Rochester
in behalf of Doctor Ames' record shows your loyalty and devotion. In I whatever way I
can help you or Doctor Brumby prepare a suitable tribute to him I would be so glad
to help. Not only that, but I am sure both Generals Kean and Truby also would be
glad to help Doctor Brumby.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSW:ktb
Mr. Gust Lambert
-4-
December 27, 1946
P. S. I am sending you a carbon copy of our interview of June 21, 1946
with some hand-written corrections by me. I would appreciate it greatly
if you would review this interview carefully and insert such changes or
corrections as you see fit. Please take your time about this. Perhaps
a friend could read it to you, which would save time and spare your eye-
sight.
In particular, would you review what you told me herein about
the little yellow fever huts and who was treated in each one. What you
told me on June 21st doesn't seem to agree with what is written in
General Truby's book, which I believe you have and which I believe he
prepared (that part of it) largely on information from you.
Let me tell you again the criteria which were used by the
Surgeon General's Office and Congress when, in 1929, they passed a bill
giving pensions and medals to certain men who had been instrumental in
the demonstration of the transmission of yellow fever. The list was pre-
pared for a Committee of the House of Representatives by the Surgeon
General of the Army after consulting with General Kean and several of his
assistants. Walter Reed and the Members of his Board, the nine men who
underwent the very repulsive fomites experiments and the American volunteers
who suffered attacks of yellow fever from experiments with infected mos-
quitoes and injections of blood were included on this list for medals
and pensions. But it was realized that the various doctors and nurses
who exposed themselves in the care of yellow fever patients in line of
duty should not be included in the list however meritorious their services
had been. The Surgeon General's reason was obvious--there would have
been no limit to such a list.
The object of the legislation was to reward those who actively
participated in the experimental work. Those who cared for the sick or
disinfected their clothes as a measure of routine sanitation were not
included. As you, of course, know, these conditions set forth by the
Surgeon'General's Office and approved by Congress excluded Doctor Ames
and others who gave excellent service in line of duty. No applicant who
was bitten but not infected was ever included, nor any man whose exposure
was not governed by the strict limitations of quarantines and scientific
controls.
